page.title: 05RELIGION
page.content: TEVERSHAM CHURCH The church at Teversham stands on the outskirts of the village, towards the north-west. The church stands in the place of one which was founded by a man who fell fighting the Danes. The walls are of field stones, flint and clunch. (Clunch is a locally quarried chalk which was cut into blocks) Many churches, walls and old houses are made of this. Teversham was first inhabited by Saxons at the time St. Etheldreda was starting her life as a nun. It is mentioned in the Domesday Book and the land was owned by the Abbey of Ely. The Bishop of Ely is still the Patron of the benefice.
